 The views and interpretations in this document are those of the authors and should not be attributed to the World Bank, to its affiliated organizations, or to any individual acting in their behalf. WORLD BANK Staff Working Paper No. 355 September 1979 THE GLOBAL FRAMEWORK A Background Study for World Development Report, 1979 This paper describes the main features of the global model system used in preparing the-World Bank's World Development Report. 1979. The system provides a quantitative-basis for the study of growth prospects in developing countries in the context of the world economy, and has been used to make pro- jections for the period 1975-90. It is not a finished product, but part of a continuing effort to improve the Bank's analytical methods. At present it consists of three main modules linked via recursive iteration: (i) models of economic activity in eleven developing "regions," together with sets of pro- jections for industrialized countries, capital surplus oil exporting coun- tries and centrally planned economies; (ii) a module describing international trade flows and commodity prices; and (iii) a module describing the global supply of various types of capital and their allocation among regions. The models for developing regions are dynamic optimizing models in the tradition of economy-wide planning models. Aggregate output of the region in question is maximized subject to constraints imposed by technology, behavior, domestic policy choices and the international economic environment. The model specifications are given in an Appendix. Prepared by: Copyright C¢ 1979 Russell J. Cheetham, The World Bank Syamaprasad Gupta and 1818 H Street, N.W. Antoine Schwartz Washington, D.C. 20433 Economic Analysis and Projections Department U.S.A.

 I. AN OVERVIEW A. Introduction 1. This paper describes the main features of the global analytical framework underlying various parts of the World Bank's World Development Report, 1979. 1/ The World Development Report (WDR) is designed to help clarify some of the linkages between the international economy and domestic strategies in the developing countries, against the background of increasing complexity in the world economy. To provide a quantitative basis for the study, a global economic model has been constructed whose purpose is to pro- ject the growth of various groups of countries and to display various pos- sible interrelationships among them, through international trade and capital flows. 2. Interest in the use of a global analytical framework for policy work within the Bank has arisen for several reasons. Firstly, because of the multiplicity of interdependent influences on growth and development in the developing countries-with no particular influence dominant--one cannot readily examine the probable impact on these economies of specific changes in, say, international trade or capital flows. A second, and related point, is the fact that the international economy is growing more interdependent; a global analytical framework can contribute to an understanding of the nature of this interdependence and to adjustments that may need to be undertaken in developing and developed countries alike. Third, there has been a growing need to ensure consistency in projections of global trade and capital accounts in various elements of policy work within the Bank. 3. The present model should be seen not as a finished product but as part of the Bank's continuing efforts to improve its analytical methods. It is not the Bank's first attempt to use an analytical framework for global analysis. Between 1974 and 1977, annual studies of the "Prospects for Devel- oping Countries" were prepared for use within the Bank; the analysis in these studies was underpinned by economic models for a sample panel of some 40 devel- oping countries, and by a simple global model called SIMLINK. 2/ The former are essentially trade-gap models in the tradition of those developed by Chenery and Strout, 3/ with an enlarged treatment of loan flows and debt service. The 1/ World Bank, World Development Report. 1979, Washington, D.C., August 1979. 2/ Hicks, Norman L., et al. (1976), "A Model of Trade and Growth for the Developing World," European Economic Review 7, pp. 239-255. 3/ Chenery, H.B., and Strout, A.M. (1966), "Foreign Assistance and Economic Development," American Economic Review 56, pp. 679-733.
 SIMLINK model extended the concepts of trade-gap models into a rudimentary global framework, which contained a large number of exogenous variables and had only a minimal number of links among country groups. SIMLINK did not include global trade accounts, had little separation of trade categories, and only rudimentary relationships between foreign capital availabilities and the output of developing countries. Since it was originally designed to study the medium-term effects of the commodity price increases that occurred in 1972-73, the model was built on the premise that the growth of developing countries was constrained principally by foreign exchange availabilities. With the passage of time, there is growing evidence to the contrary for many of these countries. These considerations, together with a need for an analy- tical framework that could help in preparing longer-term projections, led to the decision to build a new global model. 4. This work has benefited from a number of other efforts at global modeling. Several global models developed over the past decade purport to describe the functioning of the world economy and try to provide insights into the process of future development. They include studies by Forrester, Mesarovic and Pestel, 1/ for example, and the Leontief and Bariloche models. 2/ These models typically rely on a set of macro-variables to describe relations within and among a limited set of geopolitical units. They have had to use extremely simplified specifications for variables such as the growth of world population, depletion of resources, production, pollution and so on. Among this group, the Leontief model presents the most detailed specification of sectors and regions, but is completely demand-oriented and static, and ignores policy interactions. Another approach to global modeling is that taken by Project LINK which tries to link together a large number of detailed country models. 3/ Although the LINK model is designed for short-term forecasting, th. apinIb _ to cofrn* the probBstwof houikh. M - m of daft and equations. B. Concept of Regions in the Global Framework 5. There are at present some 180 countries and/or territories in the world. Since each country has, to a greater or lesser extent, an independent set of economic policies, an ideal world model might have independent modules for each country unit. This is neither technically nor managerially feasible at the present time. Given the objective of having a set of consistent global 1/ Forrester, Jay, et al. (1972), The Limits to Growth. 2/ Leontief, Wassily, et. al. (1977), The Future of the World Economy (New York: Oxford University Press); and Maelman, C. (1977), "The Bariloche Model," Chapter 5, in Deutsche et al., Problem of World Modelling (Cambridge, Mass: Ballinger Publishing Company). 3/ Ball, R.J. (ed.) (1973), International Linkage of National Economic Models (Amsterdam: North-Holland).
 accounts for trade and capital flows, the idea of linking models for a limiL,d number of individual countries was also rejected. 1/ While such an approach has the advantage of retaining identifiable units, the World Bank's own expe- rience in using only a limited number of individual country models indicates that it is frequently difficult to generate consistent global accounts at the desired level of detail. A small group of countries may be very repre- sentative with respect to, say, GDP, while being quite unrepresentative of even broad categories of international trade or capital flows. 6. The analytical framework being developed within the World Bank divides the world into 15 "regions" iu an attempt to strike a balance between the under-specification of models like that developed by Forrester, and the detail that arises from a large number of individual country models. The regional groupings currently being used are shown In Appendix 1. They in- clude eleven developing country regions, two industrialized country regions, a capital surplus oil exporting region and a centrally planned economies (CPE) region. Apart from the CPE group, these regions were established on the basis of geographical location and GNP per capita. Behind this classification are several implicit assumptions, at least with respect to the projection period 1975-1990: first, that the countries in each group face roughly similar development problems; second, that they have roughly similar economic systems (hence the separate group for the CPEs); and third, that they will, under con- ditions of choice, behave in a generally homogeneous fashion. 7. Each of the regions is treated separately in the global model, but they are brought together through a linkage mechanism that includes exports and imports of six categories of goods and services, a number of different types of capital flows, and debt service payments. How this is done is described in Section II. 1/ However, the 40 independent sample panel country models continue to be available to provide a cross-check on projections for developing country regions obtained from the global model.
 - 4 - II. THE MODEL SYSTEM A. Introduction 8. The approach taken in developing the model system was influenced by several factors: the kinds of policy issues to be addressed; theoretical considerations in specifying the nature of linkages among countries; the availability of data; and the fact that this model would be part of a contip- uing effort to improve the Bank's global analytical framework. 9. The principal interest is in the growth prospects of developing countries in an increasingly interdependent world, so there is a rather detailed treatment of these countries in the model as the earlier reference to groupings indicated. One important policy concern was the effect of var- ious patterns of international trade and capital flows on the growth of developing countries. A closely related policy issue was the effect of variations in the level of economic activity of the industrialized coun- tries on the prospects for the developing countries. These interests in- fluenced the way in which we have disaggregated global trade and capital flows and the productive sectors of the regions in the model. However, it is recognized that constraints other than foreign exchange availabilities play an important role in determining growth and structural change in par- ticular groups of developing countries. This factor has influenced our approach to modeling the domestic economic activities of the country groups. 10. The %lobal analytical framework consists of three main modules: - a set of 15 models for the individual regions defined in the system; - a module that handles international trade and commodity prices; and - a module that deals with international capital flows and their allocation among the regions. These three modules have been chosen for analytical and computational con- venience and will be described in turn below. The regional models are con- cerned with "domestic" economic activity and are calculated in constant 1975 prices. The focus of the trade module is on trade flows among regions, and these are specified in both constant 1975 prices and current prices. The capital flows module deals with the global supply of various types of capital (expressed in current prices) and their allocation among regions in a manner that is consistent with the trade flows. 11. At present, the three modules are independently calculated, but certain outputs of each are inputs to others and thus the three are linked via recursive iteration, a process which, under present specifications,
 - 5 - converges quickly. (See Figure 1 for a schematic representation of these linkages.) Keeping the three functionally separate was dictated not only by computational and analytical convenience, but also by the fact that the theoretical linkages are, in reality, poorly understood and even less well documented. Needless to say, work is being done on these linkages as part of the efforts to improve the global analytical framework. 12. It is perhaps worth pointing out that a number of variables used in the global model have been projected exogenously, some coming from supple- mentary analytical frameworks, for example, population models and commodity models, and others from independent studies (for example, OECD's analyses of growth prospects for member countries). B. The Regional Module 13. The 11 regional models for developing countries are all similar in structure; the models for the other four regions are discussed separately below. Regional Models for Developing Countries 14. These regional models are dynamic optimizing models in the tradi- tion of economy-wide planning models. Their specifications are described in Appendix II. 'For the projection period as a whole (1975-90), the aggre- gate output of the region in question is maximized subject to a number of constraints. These constraints can be classified into four groups: tech- nological; behavioral; "domestic" policy; and international environment. The first two enter as parameters estimated from time series and cross- country data; the last two groups are specified exogenously. The "domestic" policy constraints are mainly tax rates, exports, import allocations and government expenditures. The constraints imposed by the international en- vironment include the growth of world 'trade, growth of industrialized coun- tries, world commodity prices and inflation, and the supply of external capital. 15. The method by which resources are allocated within the regiornl models is familiarly known as "constrained maximization." At any period of time the regional models satisfy a consistent set of behavioral and tech- nological patterns and accounting entities and at the same time maximize growth. Changes in GDP are derived from changes in consumption and invest- ment behavior, changes in domestic and export demand, changes in technclogy and productivity, changes in the volumes and terms of trade, and changes in government policy. Accounting consistency is maintained among (i) private sector and government accounts; (ii) trade accounts; (iii) national income and product accounts; and (iv) input-output accounts. Figure 2 shows the way the model operates for a developing region.

 - 8 - 16. Production Activities. Production activities are divided into the following groups: food; non-food agriculture; metals and minerals; energy; manufactures; and services (including construction and utilities). All six sectors produce consumer and intermediate goods, but capital goods are pro- duced by only two sectors: manufacturing (i.e. equipment), and services (i.e. construction). Output is determined within an input-output framework. Two major kinds of inputs are used in the production process: intermediate mate- rial inputs and primary inputs--namely capital stocks and labor. An upper bound is placed on the growth of the agricultural sectors as.a proxy for con- straints imposed by the availability of land. Output is related to inter- mediate inputs by a set of fixed coefficients, corresponding to a given tech- nology. For lack of reliable data on capital stocks, capital enters into the production process in an incremental fashion: thus any additions to capacity depend on the availability of new investments or unused production capacity from previous periods. The relation between new investment and additional capacity (output) in each sector is determined by an incremental capital-output ratio (ICOR). Technology is fixed for any given time period, but is assumed to change over time: first, the input-output coefficients are assumed to change as the economy grows, and second, the sectoral ICORs are also assumed to change to reflect the impact of new technology on the production process. 17. The increase in output of each sector depends partly on the level of new investment, and partly on the supply of labor. Thus, in any given time period some resources may be idle. But because the model attempts to obtain the most efficient use of resources under a range of alternative pro- duction possibilities, the underutilization of resources remains at a minimal level in practice. 1/ 18. Income Generation and Consumption Activities. Income is generated from domestic and foreign sources. Domestic income is derived from the factor payments from production activities and is measured in terms of gross value added in each sector. The income from abroad includes net factor income receipts (e.g., workers' remittances and interest on foreign assets) and current transfers. The income of the private sector consists of value added, net of taxes and non-tax payments to the public sector, plus net factor income and private transfers from abroad. We assume that the private sector receives all workers' remittances from abroad, as well as dividends from private direct investments overseas. Government income comprises all domestic tax and non- tax revenues, net of subsidies, official transfers from abroad, and interest earned on foreign assets other than direct investments. 1/ See Appendix II, Section B.
 - 9 - 19o Private consumption has been made a function of net disposable income (total income from domestic and foreign sources, net of taxea and subsidies). Further, we have assumed that the consumption pattern of the private sector can be described statistically with estimated expenditure equations. Government outlays for goods and services are given exogencusly. The demand of the private and government sectors can be aggregated to deter- mine the total consumption demand for goods and services from each sector. 20. Foreign Trade. All the sectoral products except construction may be traded. The exports of each region, including non-factor service receipts, are determined exogenously, as described below. The overall level of imports of goods and non-factor services is determined by exogenously-given exports plus net capital inflows, also discussed below. The commodity composition of merchandise imports is then determined in two stages. First, imports are determined on an end-use basis, that is, they are divided into consumer goods, capital goods and intermediate goods. Demand for imported consumer goods is made a function of the Income of the private and public sectors; demand for imported capital goods is a function of capital formation, while that for intermediate goods is a function of the gross output of the reg on. These functional relations are initially estimated from past data ard then adjusted to allow for any predictable import substitution; judgments about the latter have been based on supplementary information about policy and technological changes in various groups of countries. In the second stage, the product content of merchandise imports is determined by end-use with a set of import allocation parameters; for example, imported consumer goods may consist of manufactures, non-food agricultural goods and energy products. These coef- ficients are derived from the input-output tables of the respective re&ions, and they are assumed to change as the economy grows. 21. We also assume that a certain minimum amount of each category of imports (by end-use) is essential for production and for minimum consumption needs. These so-called non-competitive or essential imports are expressed as a percentage of the total domestic demand for the category of product in question. These proportions are assumed to change along with the changes in production technology. Lastly, any surplus imports, as measured by the dif- ference between total foreign exchange available for imports and total demand for imports, are assigned among sectors by a matrix of fixed coefficients. 22. In the case of non-factor service payments, a distinction is made between freight and insurance and other non-factor services: freight and insurance payments are assumed to be proportional to the value of merchandise trade, while other non-factor service payments are projected exogenously. 23. Prices. The domestic price of each product is assumed to be the same as its international price; no adjustments are made for exchange rates and tariffs. 24. Role of Investment Demand. The total investable surplus at any time is constrained by the availability of domestic and foreign savings, and provides the financing of total investment. Domestic savings are obtained as the difference between domestic income and consumption whereas foreign savings are exogenously given.
 - 10 - 25. The model distinguishes between demand for fixed investment (in- cluding provisions for replacement), and changes in inventories. Changes in inventories are further divided, between those planned and those unplanned. The model is designed to maximize the increase in output over the projection period (it actually maximizes the discounted value of output). It does so by ensuring that t distribution of new investment over the entire projec- tion period is optimal given the various constraints in the model, including for example the exogenous set of export and government consumption demands, the need for a certain amount of non-competitive imports, and so on. 26. This constrained optimization process determines the demand for new fixed investment in each period, after taking into account replacement demand and planned changes in inventories. Replacement demand is propor- tional to gross output, the latter acting as a proxy for capital stock utilization. The demand for fixed investment in each production sector is then translated into demand for capital goods by source (i.e., equipment from the manufacturing sector, and construction from the service sector) using a matrix of capital coefficients. These coefficients are assumed to change over time to reflect secular changes in the distribution of invest- ment between plant and equipment. 27. Total demand in each sector is obtained by aggregating the demand for intermediate goods, consumption goods, fixed investment and planned in- ventories. At any given time, aggregate demand and supply in a product market are balanced by unintended changes in stocks. In practice, these stocks remain at a minimal level for two reasons: first, unintended inven- tories in one period *are used to meet planned inventory needs in the next period; and, second, the optimization process tends to allocate investment so as to minimize these inventories. 28. Terms of Trade and Foreign Capital Inflows. The net supply of foreign capital, as measured by the balance on the goods and non-factor ser- vices account, is exogenously determined in any given time period. Together with exports, also exogenously given, the inflow of foreign capital determines the aggregate import capacity. 29. Since the balance of payments accounts of each region (in particu- lar, factor incomes and capital account transactions) are projected at current prices rather than at constant 1975 prices, regional capital requirements are affected by gains or losses resulting from changes in the terms of trade. Total exports and imports at current prices are determined from the respective prices and quantities traded. For each region the combination of changing relative prices and changing commodity composition of trade means that the unit value indices for total exports and imports may diverge, thereby giving rise to gains or losses from changes In terms of trade. 30. Factor income receipts and payments include workers' remittances and dividends on private direct investment (both of which are exogenously given), interest income on foreign assets, and interest payments on external debt. As the subsequent discussion indicates, the latter are endogenously determined by the initial stock of foreign debt and by projected new loan inflows.
 - 11 - 31. Official and private transfers are both given exogenously, as is net private direct investment. Changes in the level of reserves ate deter- mined by changes in the level of imports. Two other broad categories of capital inflows are identified in the model. These are medium- and long- term loans (or liabilities) and "other capital." The latter is given'exo- genously. 1/ The balance of payments account is therefore closed by the inflow of medium- and long-term loan capital. For any given region, the inflow of loan capital is just sufficient to meet the net requirement for foreign exchange after allowing for service payments on debt (interest charges plus repayments of principal). 32. Several different categories of medium- and long-term loan capital are included in the regional model. These are; concessional loans from bilateral sources and from multilateral sources; and loans at market terms from bilateral sources, multilateral sources, and private sources. The supply of new loans from all but the private sources is given exogenously, so that it is new borrowing from private sources that balances payments. 33. Although the inflow of private loans is determined exogenously for each region, two important constraints are imposed on the level of new bor- rowing. First, there is a global constraint on the supply of loan capital from private sources for all regions. Second, the level of private borrowing by any given region is constrained by the need to keep its burden of debt ser- vice payments within reasonable limits. In the model solutions, the need to maintain a reasonable degree of external financial stability emerged as an important constraint on the level of borrowing in several developing reglons. Treatment of Industrialized Countri'es and Other Regions 34. To a large extent, the projections for the two industrialized country regions (industrialized Europe, and North America, Japan arid Oceanfa),-the cen- trally planned economies, and the capital surplus oil exporters are exogenous. In the case of the OECD countries, the limits of our time and manpower, the complexity of the economies and their sheer size, all suggested that these parts of the global model should be exogenous, at least for the time leing. The main reason for treating the other two regions exogenously was the lack of data, and, in the case of the CPEs, our limited understanding of the work- ings of these economies. 35. The projections of GNP for the industrialized country regions rely heavily on the work of other agencies, notably the OECD and the IMF. The exports and imports of these two regions are initially determined exogenously. 1/ Although this item is treated as a single variable in the model, it in- cludes changes in short-term assets and liabilities, changes in medium- and long-term assets, allocation of SDRs, capital subscriptions, capital not elsewhere included, errors and omissions.
 - 12 - Exports are projected using the same method as for the other regions, which is explained below. Imports are related to GDP by commodity-specific elas- ticities. Ultimately, however, both OECD imports and exports are modified through a global adjustment procedure. 36. For all of these regions only the current accounts of the balance of payments have been fully specified; complete capital accounts have not been spelled out, in view of the difficulties of handling the interrelations between the international capital market and the balance of payments accounts of these regions. Certain capital account items related to ODA flows from those regions have been projected, as the subsequent discussion of the capital flow module indicates. These are mainly the net flows of concessional loans to developing countries, subscriptions to international organizations and official export credits to LDCs. C. The International Trade Module 37. In the present model the growth of world trade is constrained by the GDP growth of the OECD regions, to which it is related by a fixed elas- ticity. The latter was estimated taking account of past shifts in the rela- tionship, from the pre-trade liberalization period of the fifties to the "trade creation" era of the sixties. The relationship between world trade and OECD growth seems likely to remain significant: the small share of the developing countries in world markets at present implies that they are not likely to have a significant impact on the overall growth of world trade within the projection period. 38. The projections of primary exports from each region are exogenous, and are based on the Bank's regular analysis of world market prospects for major primary commodities. Projections of export volumes of 35 individual commodities from major supplying countries are based on the same assumptions about OECD growth and international inflation as those used in the global framework, and are subsequently aggregated into the regional format and trade classification used in the global model. Though this sample of 35 commodities is an incomplete one, it is nevertheless regarded as representative of the total trade in each category for each region. 1/ 1/ Roughly speaking, the commodities covered by the detailed analysis accounted for 70% of LDC total merchandise export earnings in 1975. The commodity samples are more representative for some regions than for others; they are generally more representative for the developing than for the industrialized countries. Moreover, the smaller the share of a given commodity in a region's exports, the less represen- tative the sample.
 - 13 - 39. As primary exports are specified exogenously, global consistency in the trade module is maintained by successive adjustments of regional imports (the method of adjustment is described below). The volume of priliary trade is therefore essentially determined by supply. At least for food and energy, this is not unrealistic. Given the pre-determined level of world merchandise trade on the one hand, and the exogenous primary export projec- tions on the other, the global level of trade in manufactures is therefore fixed at the outset. The regional distribution of imports and exports of manufactures is arrived at through successive rounds of adjustments, sub- ject to the global constraint, starting with the first set of exogenous projections of regional exports. 40. In the case of exports, changes may be made in the assumptions about the growth of specific commodity groups, whereas for imports the adjust- ments are achieved by varying the assumptions about regional rates of import substitution. 41. This global integration procedure has the disadvantage that it ignores the origin and destination structure of trade. But although bilateral flows are not explicitly formulated in the integrated version of the global model, they can nevertheless be estimated once the overall model solution is obtained. For that purpose an iterative technique has been used, originating from input-output analysis. I/ The elements of a base period matrix are sub- jected to successive row- and column-wise adjustments, under the constraint of new "desired" row and column totals. Given the base period matrix of in- terregional trade and projected regional imports and exports, a consistent set of bilateral trade projections is derived for any given commodity. In effect, each bilateral flow is a fui.nttion of the total imports of the region of destination and the total exports of the region of origin. This method provides a consistent synthesis, even if a rather mechanical one, of- the independent supply and demand constraints imposed on regional trade through the global adjustment procedure. The method allows us to interpret the results of the global adjustment approach in terms of implied shifts in the interregional structure of trade. D. The Capital Flows Module 42. The global capital flows module includes a set of assumptions about the supply of various types of capital available to the LDC regions in the model, and a procedure for allocating the supplies among these regions. As 1/ Richard Stone (1963), "Input-Output Relations 1954-66. A Program for Growth," Series 3, Department of Applied Economics, University of Cambridge.
 - 14 - already noted, we have not attempted to include the capital accounts of the industrialized countries, the CPEs or the capital surplus oil exporters in the model at this stage. As explained above, the developing country regions' demand for external capital arises from the need to finance net imports of goods and non-factor services, to service debt and to maintain reserves. We are here concerne, with ensuring that the LDC regions' demand for each cate- gory of capital balances the projected supply. 43. Sources of Supply. The capital flows module includes four different types of capital flows: transfers from official and private sources; private direct investment; medium- and long-term loans, and "other" capital. 44. The projections of transfers distinguish between official transfers (that is, transfers received by the reporting country's official sector), and private transfers. It is assumed that the total supply of official transfers available to the LDCs is equivalent to Official Development Assistance (ODA), that is, bilateral grants (net of technical assistance from the industrialized country regions) together with grants from the capital surplus oil exporting regions and from international organizations. These projections of official transfers are made in connection with the projections of total ODA which are discussed below. Private transfers to LDCs are projected independently, and partly depend on the projected economic conditions in the developed countries. 45. Private direct investment in LDCs is projected independently on the basis of what is currently known about the climate for private invest- ment and about the intentions of investors and host countries. The category "other capital," also projected exogenously, is in practice dominated by short-term capital, and we expect this to continue to be the case at least through the mid-1980s. The growth in "other" capital is hence related broadly to the growth in the imports of LDCs. 46. We have made an explicit assumption about the supply of each cate- gory of medium- and long-term loans. The main categories identified in the model are as follows: Loans at Concessional Terms From bilateral sources (DAC, OPEC, other) From multilateral sources Loans at Market Rates Official export credits From multilateral sources From private sources Suppliers' credits Financial markets
 - 15 - 47. The supply of concessional loans is derived from the supply of ODA from the OECD Development Assistance Committee, OPEC and other sources. Total ODA is projected independently for each source; for DAC members the supply is related to their projected GNP. Four types of ODA flows are distinguished for each category of donor; technical assistance, grants, bilateral loans, and flows to multilateral institutions. The portion of ODA that is technical assistance does not generally appear in the balance of payments of recipieut countries, as it is seldom possible to ascertain and record the receipts involved, so these flows are excluded from the receipts of the LDC regions in the model. Flows to multilateral institutions are treated separately. Although these contributions form a part of, and are a claim on, the total official resources made available by donor governments, they do not flow directly to developing countries. The flow of ODA from these multilateral institutions to the LDC regions in the model is also projected exogenously; in general, it is related to the projected flows from donors to these insti- tutions. 48. Loans at market rates--official export credits, private suppliers' credits, and loans at market terms from multilateral sources--are all pro- jected exogenously. Those from multilateral sources are projected on the basis of announced lending intentions. 49. As indicated earlier loans from private financial markets are used to balance the external accounts of the LDC regions in the model. Because of the global constraint imposed on the growth in supply of these loans to LDCs, the original projection of the aggregate demand for loan funds had to be adjusted downwards. 50. The various categories of capital are allocated among the regions according to several criteria,including, for example, historical patterns, the announced intentions of various donor groups, in the case of ODA, and the ability of the various regions to absorb loans at market terms. In prac- tice, the final allocation is arrived at in an iterative way with a series of adjustments being made to-the allocation of loans from private financial markets. E. Treatment of International Prices 51. The integration of real and monetary variables in the global analy- tical framework is less than complete. There is no detailed supply and demand model which simultaneously determines prices and quantities by commodity group and region. Rather, relative unit values are projected independently from real trade flows and subsequently inflated to take into account an assumed rate of world inflation. 52. The disadvantages of this approach are not likely to be very serious in that dramatic and lasting changes in relative prices are not anticipated. Moreover, since our analysis focuses essentially on the medium to long term,
 - 16 - it is more concerned with structural trends than with fluctuations around these trends. A more serious weakness, however, is that the present frame- work cannot analyze the effects on comparative advantages of relative changes in production costs brought about by differential exchange rate movements and pricing policies among or within regions. Current efforts are seeking to make real trade flows price-sensitive, by specifying region- and commodity- specific price elasticities of supply and demand. 53. In the analytical framework the rate of global inflation is given exogenously by an international price index. This price index is used to deflate all service account transactions and capital flows in the model. 54. The commodity price indices for food, non-food agriculture, metals and minerals, and energy are derived from independent analysis of supply and demand prospects for the sample of 35 commodities. 55. In contrast to those for primary commodities, the unit value in- dices used for trade in manufactures do not rely on projections of inter- national prices for individual products. In order to account for relevant differences in the product composition of manufactured exports by origin and destination, four different unit value indices of manufactured exports are distinguished, relating to exports from and to industrialized and devel- oping countries. 1/ Projections are based on regression analysis that relates these indices to an index of global inflation. 56. While the unit values for the individual commodity categories are exogenously given, the overall trade deflators for each region are endogenous, in the sense that they take account of changes in the commodity composition of regional trade flovs. As discussed earlier, the international prices of products are incorporated in the regional models. 1/ UN, Monthly Bulletin of Statistics, Special Table F. June 1977 and 1978.
 - 17 - III. DATA. MODEL ESTIHATION AND VALIDATION 57. Assembling data for the global model involved four main tasks: (1) construction of a set of global accounts for 1975 to act as a set of initial conditions for the model; (ii) estimation of parameters for each region for the base year 1975; (iii) projection of changes in the base year values of parameters for 1980, 1985 and 1990; and (iv) projection of changes in the exogenous variables in the model. The estimates of future values for parameters and exogenous variables are, for obvious reasons, necessarily uncertain, but it is our belief that while rough they are generally plausible, and that they provide a solid base for future improvements. 58. Ihe data used in the study were drawn mainly from the extensive set of social and economic statistics assembled within the World Bank from various international, regional, and national institutions. A. Global Accounts for the Base Year 59. A major effort was mounted to develop a set of national income, balance of payments and trade accounts for each region for the base year 1975. (The choice of a base year was largely dictated by the availability of data.) This was a two-stage process: a preliminary set of regional accounts was first obtained by aggregating the data for individual coun- tries into relevant regional totals; a final set of regional accounts was then obtained by adjusting those preliminary regional accounts for which sufficient data on individual countries were not available. The numbers of countries for which various sets of data were available are reported in Table 1:
 - 18 - Table 1: NUMBER OF COUNTRIES FOR WHICH ACTUAL DATA OR ESTIMATES AVAILABLE FOR 1975 Capital Surplus Data Set LDCs OPEC CPEs DCs Total National Accounts 90 3 12 /a 20 113 /b Population/Labor Force 107 6 12 20 145 Trade 81 5 12 20 118 /c Balance of Payments 87 3 .. 20 110 MLT Loan Flows & Debt 71 .. .. .. 71 /a For the centrally planned economies only total GNP was available. /b Excluding CPEs. /c At the commodity breakdown level data are available for only 97 countries. Not available. 60. The regional national income accounts comprise data on the industrial origin of gross domestic product (GDP) at factor cost and on expenditures or GDP at market prices. The preliminary accounts for LDCs were based on data for 90 developing countries (which account for 96X of the total GDP of devel- oping countries) and all industrialized countries. The input-output coeffi- cient matrices, derived from data prepared by Carter and Petrie of Brandeis University for the Leontief study, 1/ were the major tools used in disaggre- gating the regional national income accounts into commodity balances for the six production sectors specified in the regional models. 61. The merchandise imports and exports of each region were calculated from United Nations trade data. Once the totals were established the next step was to expand these accounts to cover the origin and destination of merchandise trade among the 15 regions in the model. This was done by com- bining the above accounts with United Nations data about trade flows amung certain groups of countries. 1/ The Future of the World Economy, op. cit.
 - 19 - 62. The preliminary regional estimates of the balance of payments accounts were derived by merging data from the International Monetary Fund, the United Nations and the World Bank's Debt Reporting System (DRS) with the estimates of merchandise trade just mentioned. Among the "invisible" items of the current account, data on non-factor service and factor service income were obtained from IMF, except for those on interest payments, which were taken from the DRS. 1/ For the items in the capital account, as well as re- serves, estimates were obtained from IMF data, with the exception of "Medium and Long-term Loan Capital" which was obtained from the DRS. B. Parameter Estimation 63. The parameters used in the regional models, and the sources of data from which estimates have been made, are summarized in Table 2. 64. The input-output coefficients were derived from input-output matrices prepared for the Leontief study, after reaggregation into the sectoral and regional groups used in the World Bank model. As in the United Nations study we have assumed that the coefficients are income-specific and that they change over time with changes in per capita income, the latter being taken as an index of the overall level of economic and technical development of the region in question. 1/ Because of data limitations, origin-destination accounts were not prepared for non-factor services.

(Country aggregate) for food. i , UN data for fuel. ( to UN data Commodity composition of capital, Region specific. ILO data (Country aggregate) * Denotes parameters whose values change during the projection period.

 - 25 - APPDXD II Table Al: Variables Endogenous X, sectoral gross output F, sectoral final demands V, sectoral value added P, sectoral domestic prices Cr, C%, rural and urban sectorsl WP, sectoral vorld prices consumptions d, discount prices IS, sectoral investments by sources ICS, idle capacity E, sectoral exports WI, world income sum over regions (n-i) ET, total exports RP, relative prioes in the international M, sectoral imports (essential); market (i.e., in relation to imports that represent behavior total) under normal circumstances STO, stocks (unplanned) IV,, total imports mr, allocation parkeoter for surplus MS, sectoral imports by sources imports UBS, surplus Imports xoCnous Exogenous Polley POP, population GC, government consumption vector IT, terminal period investment I, tariff rate indexes Pe, labor productivity change L, labor force supply Pr, rural population Pu, urban population VIR, world inflation rate
 - 26 - APPENDIX II Table A2: Parameters Endogenous Econometrically Estimated Exogenous Policy ICOR, capital output Cor, CO , rural and urban R, discount rates ratios u committed con- sumption MSS, import sub- B, product matrix of stitution capital coefficients Br, Bu, allocation coefficient parameter and capital output of consumption ratio matrices T, tax rates (in normalized form) e,, demand elasticity for import A, input-output matrix e2, relative price elasticity of Imports VA, value added ratios e , demand elasticity of 6, replacement of imports matrices eb, price (relative) elasticity y, conversion matrix4 of exports from source to destination for e59 labor coefficient matrix investments
 - 27 - APPENDIX II B. FURTHER EXPLANATION OF THE SPECIFICATIONS The Objective Function i. Volume of Production as the Maximand max E A P'(F - MS). tt This is a rather unconventional formulation. It attempts to maximize some measure of efficiency in the use of resources. Efficiency has been defined as the returns from the use of resources, measured in terms of real value added deflated by a discounting factor. We have used final demands (exports, con- sumption, and investment) minus imports as a proxy for value added; since the former concepts are based on product classifications, we can use relevant prices to deflate each of them. Ideally, one should choose "profit" as the maximand. In that case, the solution values could approximate the "von Neumann growth path." ii. Consumption as the Maximand, as an Alternative Objective Function max E A tP(C + Cr) t U r The decision regarding resource allocation is guided mainly by the consideration of maximizing the discounted value of real consumption aver the projection period. In the detailed discussions to follow it is made clear that, unlike most other macro-economic linear programming models, the present model's specification does not provide for any intertemporal choice in the sectoral shares of consumption. The maximand (i.e., total consumption) can be affected, in this case, only by sectoral reallocation of income and its intertemporal path. Consumption propensities are strictly behavioral; in discounting the future consumption stream, we adopted an exogenously determined international discount rate. Because of the lack of consumption choices (consumption propensi- ties are predetermined by behavior), the solution values under the "consump-.. tion maximand" are very close to the solution values under the "value added maximand" in our present exercise. But there is one minor difference: depend- ing on the values of consumption, production, and investment parameters, the two alternative approaches (with different "maximands") might yield two dif- ferent sectoral compositions of output. For example, if the rural sector (i.e., agricultural activities) has a higher propensity to save than the
 - 28 - APPENDIX II urban sector but a comparatively lower incremental capital! output ratio, the consumption maximand might favor less production in the rural (i.e., agricul- tural growth) than in the urban sector as compared with the latter approach. Nonetheless, conceptually, any variant of consumption as the maximand with a. set of ELES consumption functions with the existing constraints leads to double. optimization. 1/ Halor Constraints i. Allocation of Investment The methods of sectoral allocation of investment used in the model provide its main dynamics. Investments are allocated between sectors by their rates of return, evaluated by the relative prices of the current period. In any period, fixed investment in a sector will be sufficient to provide the minimum additional capacity needed to generate output (with a one year lag) to match the consumption, investment, and export demands (net of imports) of the next period. In this investment decision, the investor first tries to utilize all existing capacity before assessing the needs for additional -capacity. However, there are circumstances where even over-investment will be economical. For example, if certain essential primary inputs are avail- able only in the present period, and cannot be transferred to the next period, then it is economical tQ use them as inputs for investment during the present period and transfer them to the future period in the form of idle capacity. IS > 8aX + 6K - ICS-1 In the above equation, X depicts the fixed new investment and working capital, whereas K gives the replacement investment. B and 4 give the capital coefficient matrices for both types of investments. They are also normalized. They carry a time conscript since they change over time, according to the per capita income of the economy (used as a proxy for the stage of technological development). Similarly, and by the same logic, the values of ICORs are changed with respect to GDP growth, i.e., updated outside the model with respect to previous GDP growth. 11 See J. Benard, "Duality and Second-Best Characteristics in the Regional Sub-Kodel Framework," Economic Analysis and Projections Department Working Paper, World Bank, October 1978.
 - 29 - APPENDIX II ii. Treatment of the Foreign Trade Sector The total resource transfers (measured as the current account bal- ance) from one country or region to another are determined by policy. Given. exogenously determined "net factor income" and "current transfers," the trade balance for any country is preassigned. 1/ Exports being known (by the export demand equation)., total imports are predetermined. Sectoral imports are, however, determined endogenously as a solution value in the model. Imports are divided into two groups: essential and non-essential. The essential imports (of any commodity) by any sector are elastic with respect to both price and demand. The price elasticity is measured in terms of the percentage change in the imports of the commodity in response to a percentage clhange in the relative price of the commodity 'in the international market. The demand elasticity 2/ is defined as the percentage change in imports in response to a given percentage change in the total demand for that commodity by the importers. The total demiand to be used for estimating the demand elasticity may arise-from consumers, producers, or investors. For example,,demand for machinery can be taken as proportional to the volume;of capital formation, given unchanged relative prices. The problem of import substitution has been treated(ia two ways. One part of import substitutions takes place In response to changes in rela- tive prices, and the other part is dependent on the-changes in technology and policies. The term MSS ("surplus" imports) captures the latter aspect of import substitution, and it is made exogenous in most cases. In this scheme, only when non-essential imports vanish does the availability of foreign exchange act as a binding=constraint .(trade -con- straint) on growth. iii. Sectoral Balances The sectoral balances in an economy are represented as GC < (1- A)X - Cr - Cr - IS - E + MS + STO 1- 1/ It assumes that foreign exchange reserves cannot accumulate beyond the value of several months' worth of imports. which are set exogenously in the model. 2/ A derived measure and not strictly an estimated parameter. 3/ This is necessary because of the upper bound set on the accumulation of reserves, described above.
 - 30 - APPENDIX II Government consumption (GCit) is exogenous. The supply of any sec.tor. in any year ec~t ls production plus imports. Demand originates from consumption (rural + urban), investment, and exports. If supply and demand do not: match, unintended stocks absorb the shock. In the next period, they are.carried over and added to the supply side of the identity. Since stocks do not appear in the value of the maximand (i.e., they have, conceptually, a zero.price coefficient), the program keeps stocks at.the minimam level.

doc.abstracts: This paper describes the main features of the global model system used in preparing the World Bank's World Development Report, 1979. The system provides a quantitative basis for the study of growth prospects in developing countries in the context of the world economy, and has been used to make projections for the period 1975-90. It is not a finished product, but part of a continuing effort to improve the Bank's analytical methods. At present it consists of three main modules linked via recursive iteration: (i) models of economic activity in eleven developing regions, together with sets of projections for industrialized countries, capital surplus oil exporting countries and centrally planned economies; (ii) a module describing international trade flows and commodity prices; and (iii) a module describing the global supply of various types of capital and their allocation among regions. The models for developing regions are dynamic optimizing models in the tradition of economy-wide planning models. Aggregate output of the region in question is maximized subject to constraints imposed by technology, behavior, domestic policy choices and the international economic environment.
doc.subtopic: Environmental Economics & Policies,Banks & Banking Reform,Economic Theory & Research,Markets and Market Access,Free Trade
